hints.label: def-stochastic-process-histories
hints.title: Stochastic Process and Histories
hints.content:
111: :label: def-stochastic-process-histories
112: 
113: A **discrete-time stochastic process** $\{X_t\}_{t \in \mathbb{Z}}$ with values in a finite alphabet $\mathcal{A}$ is characterized by:
114: 
115: - **Past at time $t$**: $\overleftarrow{X}_t = \ldots X_{t-2} X_{t-1}$ (semi-infinite sequence)
116: - **Future from time $t$**: $\overrightarrow{X}_t = X_t X_{t+1} X_{t+2} \ldots$ (semi-infinite sequence)
117: - **Joint distribution**: $P(\overleftarrow{X}_t, \overrightarrow{X}_t)$ characterizes the process

108: ### 2.1. Background: Computational Mechanics
109: 
110: :::{prf:definition} Stochastic Process and Histories
111: :label: def-stochastic-process-histories
112: 
113: A **discrete-time stochastic process** $\{X_t\}_{t \in \mathbb{Z}}$ with values in a finite alphabet $\mathcal{A}$ is characterized by:
114: 
115: - **Past at time $t$**: $\overleftarrow{X}_t = \ldots X_{t-2} X_{t-1}$ (semi-infinite sequence)
116: - **Future from time $t$**: $\overrightarrow{X}_t = X_t X_{t+1} X_{t+2} \ldots$ (semi-infinite sequence)
117: - **Joint distribution**: $P(\overleftarrow{X}_t, \overrightarrow{X}_t)$ characterizes the process

hints.label: def-causal-states-epsilon-machine
hints.title: Causal States and ε-Machines
hints.content:
123: :label: def-causal-states-epsilon-machine
124: 
125: **Causal equivalence:** Two pasts $\overleftarrow{x}$ and $\overleftarrow{x}'$ are **causally equivalent** (denoted $\overleftarrow{x} \sim_\varepsilon \overleftarrow{x}'$) if they induce identical conditional distributions over futures:
126: 
127: $$
128: P(\overrightarrow{X} \mid \overleftarrow{X} = \overleftarrow{x}) = P(\overrightarrow{X} \mid \overleftarrow{X} = \overleftarrow{x}')
129: 
130: $$
131: 
132: **Causal state:** The equivalence class $[\overleftarrow{x}]_\varepsilon$ is a **causal state** $\sigma \in \Sigma_\varepsilon$.
133: 
134: **ε-machine:** The pair $(\Sigma_\varepsilon, T_\varepsilon)$ where:
135: - $\Sigma_\varepsilon$ is the set of causal states
136: - $T_\varepsilon: \Sigma_\varepsilon \times \mathcal{A} \to \text{Dist}(\Sigma_\varepsilon)$ is the transition function

hints.label: def-coarse-graining-map
hints.title: Coarse-Graining Maps and Macro-Processes
hints.content:
142: :label: def-coarse-graining-map
143: 
144: A **coarse-graining map** $f: \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{B}$ maps microscopic observables to macroscopic observables.
145: 
146: The **induced macro-process** is $Y_t = f(X_t)$.

hints.label: def-information-closure
hints.title: Information Closure
hints.content:
154: :label: def-information-closure
155: 
156: A coarse-graining $f: X \to Y$ satisfies **information closure** if the macroscopic process $Y$ is as predictable from its own past as from the microscopic past:
157: 
158: $$
159: I(\overrightarrow{Y}_t ; \overleftarrow{Y}_t) = I(\overrightarrow{Y}_t ; \overleftarrow{X}_t)
160: 
161: $$
162: 
163: where $I(A;B)$ is the mutual information.
hints.section: ## 2. Preliminaries: ε-Machines, υ-Machines, and Closure Types
hints.raw_directive:
151: ### 2.2. Closure Types
152: 
153: :::{prf:definition} Information Closure
154: :label: def-information-closure
155: 
156: A coarse-graining $f: X \to Y$ satisfies **information closure** if the macroscopic process $Y$ is as predictable from its own past as from the microscopic past:
157: 
158: $$
159: I(\overrightarrow{Y}_t ; \overleftarrow{Y}_t) = I(\overrightarrow{Y}_t ; \overleftarrow{X}_t)
160: 
161: $$
162: 
163: where $I(A;B)$ is the mutual information.
164:

hints.label: def-computational-closure
hints.title: Computational Closure
hints.content:
169: :label: def-computational-closure
170: 
171: A coarse-graining $f: X \to Y$ satisfies **computational closure** if the macro-ε-machine can be obtained by coarse-graining the micro-ε-machine.
172: 
173: Formally, there exists a projection $\pi: \Sigma_\varepsilon^{(X)} \to \Sigma_\varepsilon^{(Y)}$ such that:
174: 
175: $$
176: \pi([\overleftarrow{x}]_\varepsilon^{(X)}) = [f(\overleftarrow{x})]_\varepsilon^{(Y)}
177: 
178: $$
179: 
180: and the transition dynamics commute:
181: 
182: $$
183: T_\varepsilon^{(Y)}(\pi(\sigma), y) = \pi(T_\varepsilon^{(X)}(\sigma, f^{-1}(y)))
184: 
185: $$

hints.label: def-causal-closure
hints.title: Causal Closure
hints.content:
191: :label: def-causal-closure
192: 
193: Define the **υ-machine** $(\Sigma_\upsilon, T_\upsilon)$ whose states partition micro-pasts by their induced macro-futures:
194: 
195: $$
196: \overleftarrow{x} \sim_\upsilon \overleftarrow{x}' \iff P(\overrightarrow{Y} \mid \overleftarrow{X} = \overleftarrow{x}) = P(\overrightarrow{Y} \mid \overleftarrow{X} = \overleftarrow{x}')
197: 
198: $$
199: 
200: A coarse-graining satisfies **causal closure** if:
201: 
202: $$
203: \Sigma_\varepsilon^{(Y)} = \Sigma_\upsilon
204: 
205: $$

hints.label: thm-closure-equivalence
hints.title: Equivalence of Closure Types
hints.content:
211: :label: thm-closure-equivalence
212: 
213: (Ortega et al., 2024, Theorem 1)
214: 
215: For any coarse-graining $f: X \to Y$:
216: 
217: $$
218: \text{Information Closure} \iff \text{Causal Closure}
219: 
220: $$
221: 
222: Furthermore (Theorem 2), for **spatial coarse-grainings** (where $f$ aggregates spatially local variables):
223: 
224: $$
225: \text{Information Closure} \implies \text{Computational Closure}

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-123
hints.title: Lumpability Connection
hints.content:
231: :class: note
232: 
233: Computational closure is closely related to **lumpability** in Markov chain theory (Kemeny & Snell, 1976). A partition of states is **strongly lumpable** if the transition probabilities depend only on the partition classes, not the specific states.
234: 
235: **Key distinction:** Lumpability is a property of a single Markov chain with respect to a partition. Computational closure is a property of a *sequence* of Markov chains under iterated coarse-graining (the RG flow).
